WILLIAM HEBBORN. I am a porter. This is my truck. I never sent the prisoner for it, or authorised him to get possession of it. I have not seen it since. I took him on the 17th of November. He said he had taken it away, but never said what had become of it. I could not find him before.

Prisoner's Defence. A man came and asked if I wanted a job; he took me up the wharf, and I assisted him with the truck. - Another man joined us, and they took me to Bow, and at last both went away; - they returned, and began swearing, and saying it was not worth the trouble; they could get but 12s. for it.
GUILTY . Aged 53.
Confined Three Months .

253.
JOHN GLOVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , 1 shoe, value 5s. the goods of
George Goodeve
.

EUPHEMIA GOODEVE
. I am the wife of George Goodeve, a shoemaker ; we live in Fenchurch-street
. The prisoner came in on the 5th of December and offered some saw-dust for sale; I said we wanted none; he still stood there; I told him to go along, and at last he went: - he had been standing with his back to the window in the shop - he returned in a few minutes - stood in the same place, and told me the price of the saw-dust; I told him to go along; he was turning round, and I saw this shoe in his hand, under a sack, which he had on his shoulder: I called a gentleman in, and he was secured; he dropped it, and the gentleman brought it in. - The fellow one was taken the first time he came, I suppose, as both were there before he came.

JOHN JUDD
. - I am an officer, and have the shoe.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Six Months .

254.
RAYMOND DRAKE
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM HUMPHREYS
. I am a green-grocer , and live in St. Dunstan's-hill
. The prisoner was my servant , and intrusted to receive money for me; he had 13s. a week, and his breakfast; he should account to me directly he received money; Reynolds bought coals of me - the prisoner never accounted to me for money received from him on the 30th of October .

RICHARD REYNOLDS
. I am a broker. On the 30th of October, between three and four o'clock, I paid the prisoner, 3s. 2d. for two bushels of coals - I am sure there was one shilling among the money I gave him; he gave me this receipt. (read.)

WILLIAM HUMPHREYS. I did not ask him for this money; he was discharged on the 4th of November, and on the 6th I received information; he called on me - I said I had learned that he had received some money, and not accounted for it, and said I should be obliged if he would tell me if he had received any more; he said he had received this of Mr. Reynolds.
NOT GUILTY .

255.
RAYMOND DRAKE
was again indicted for the
like offence .

WILLIAM HUMPHREYS
. The prisoner never paid me any money received from
Elizabeth Read
on the 30th of October ; he took out goods, and if he was paid for them, he should bring me the money directly.

Cross-examined by Mr. BARRY. Q. You have a good business I suppose? A. Yes, and keep books; I discovered this account before the prisoner called; he acknowledged receiving it; he had to pay me several small sums in the course of the day.
ELIZABETH READ. I deal with Humphreys. The prisoner brought coals and potatoes to my house; I paid the prisoner four separate shillings on the 30th of October, for his master; he gave me no receipt.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you recollect the day? A. I remember it very well.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Six Months .

256.
JAMES DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
William Wyllie
, from his person .

WILLIAM WYLLIE. On the 9th of November I was on Snow-hill
- I put my hand to my pocket, and my handkerchief was gone; I turned round, and saw the prisoner drop it; I seized him, took him into a shop, and gave charge of him.

GEORGE CORBY
. I am an officer. I took him in charge, and found a handkerchief on him, which he said was his mother's.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Several witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined One Month and
Whipped .

257.
JAMES DONOVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of November , 1 cloak, value 16s. , the goods of
William Petherbridge
.

WILLIAM THOMAS VIZER
. I am servant to William Petherbridge, a linen-draper , of Holborn-bridge
. On the 3d of November, I heard a noise at the door, went out, and went up a court close by, and at the top saw the prisoner stuffing this cloak into his bosom; I brought him back, and he acknowledged the offence.

GEORGE CORBY
. I took him in charge; he appeared in distress.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded great distress.
GUILTY . Aged 55.
Confined Six Months .

258.
THOMAS PERKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of November , 1 piece of leaden pipe, value 3s., and 1 brass-cock, fixed to the same, value 2s., the goods of
James Harding, the elder
, and
James Harding, the younger
, and fixed to a certain building of theirs; and 3 chisels, value 1s., the goods of
George Crowhurst
.
2d COUNT, stating the pipe to belong to James Harding, the elder, only.

JOSEPH RIESHA
. I am a watchman of Coleman-street. I went on duty at seven o'clock on the 23d of November, and at the end of Finsbury-circus
and London-wall, I saw the prisoner coming over some boards - I laid hold of him by his wooden-leg, and said, "You must go to the watch-house" - I searched him, and found this pipe and cock on him.

WILLIAM PAGE
. I am an officer. I found this property on the prisoner at the watch-house - I compared it with what remains at the building - it fits exactly - it is a water-pipe, and was fixed to the cistern.
GEORGE CROWHURST. These three chisels are mine, and were on Messrs. Harding's premises.

JAMES HARDING, JUN. This building was in the Circus, facing the London Institution - it is in the City - it belongs to my father only - I am in partnership with him, but not in this building; I have seen the pipe fitted with what remains - it fits exactly.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

259.
CHARLOTTE EVERSFIELD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of November , 1 half-crown, and 4 shillings, the monies of
Thomas Alexander Forbes
, her master .

THOMAS HATFIELD
. I am in the employ of Mr. Forbes, a butcher of Newgate-market
- the prisoner was about six weeks in his service. On the 4th of November, between five and six o'clock in the evening, I was minding the shop, outside, and saw her come up the passage, and go behind the door - I went near her, and saw her hand in the till, taking out some money; she took her hand out- I turned round, and saw her go down into the kitchen - I do not know what the till contained; I told my master; who got an officer.
THOMAS ALEXANDER FORBES. Hatfield gave me information - I fetched an officer, who searched her - I do not know what the till contained.

LEWIS FACHE
. I am an officer. I asked the prisoner if she had any money in her pocket; she said, No; I found on her half-crown, four shillings, and 5 1/2d.
NOT GUILTY .

260.
JOHN HUMPHRIES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of November , 4 stone-bottles, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas James Wallington
.

JOHN MORELAND
. I am a patrol of St. Sepulchre's. On the 19th of November, at a quarter-past five o'clock, I saw the prisoner close to Mr. Wallington's premises; I was about thirty yards off - he advanced till he was within about fifteen yards of me - I went and collared him with these four stone-bottles under his arm - he said he had picked them up on the steps of the door.

THOMAS JAMES WALLINGTON. About five o'clock in the evening, this occurred - I knew one of these bottles, for I had marked it, having lost ten or twelve dozens on the Thursday evening before; this was taken on Sunday; my cellar had been fastened up; the bars were removed- a person could get his head in and reach them.
Prisoner's Defence. I found them on the steps of the door.
NOT GUILTY .

261.
GEORGE WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of November , 3lbs. weight of tobacco, value 10s. , the goods of
James Taddy
, and others.

WILLIAM HIETT
. I am in the employ of James Taddy, and others, his partners, tobacconists , of No. 45, Minories
- the prisoner was employed by a man, who works on their premises by the piece; it is my duty to examine them when they leave work. On the 14th of November, about ten minutes to seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoner was leaving work - I searched him at the entrance of the passage, and found in his hat, which he had over his shoulder, a quantity of leaf-tobacco; it was three parts full- there were about 3lbs. of it - I gave information, and he was taken in charge - he had been there three months - I know nothing against him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is it not your habit to search all the boys? A. Yes; he did not tell me he had picked it up, intending to place it on a cask; it had a handkerchief over it - he must have took the handkerchief out to have his hat searched - he knew that - I saw no basin or plate in his hand.
COURT. Q. Is it your usual way to rub them down? A. Yes; and then they pull off their hats.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am an officer, and took him with the hat and tobacco.

JAMES TOMLIN
. I am one of this firm. It is Hiett's duty to search the men and boys; the prisoner has worked for us about nine months in all.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming out of the room and picked it up - I robbed nobody.
One witness gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months .

262.
PATRICK MEREDITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of November , 16 lbs. of beef, value 8s. , the goods of
William Gilbert
.

WILLIAM GILBERT. I am a butcher , and live in Long-lane, West-Smithfield
. On the 11th of November I was writing at the back of the shop - somebody on the pavement asked if I had not missed something; I looked, and missed a piece of sirloin of beef; I was told the man had gone up Long-lane; I and the patrol followed, and caught the prisoner with this beef under his arm; I knew it to be mine.

JOHN MORELAND
. I am a patrol. I came up to the corner of Charter-house-street - a lad directed me up Long-lane; I went up, and took the prisoner with the beef, which Mr. Gilbert claimed.

GEORGE GODFREY
. I received him in charge at the watch-house, and found some sham gold seals on him - he is a duffer, and sells these articles - he seemed a little drunk when he was taken, but, before we searched him, he got excessively drunk without more drink.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Publicly Whipped and Discharged .

263.
JOHN GOODMAN
and
ANTHONY FORMAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
Henry Frazier
, from his person .

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am an officer. On the 9th of November I was at the end of Blackfriars-bridge
, at the time the Lord Mayor was on the water; I saw the prisoners together, following a lady and gentleman; Forman took the handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, and gave it to Goodman; I crossed over, and told the gentleman - he caught Goodman, and snatched the handkerchief out of his hand; he said his name was Frazier, but did not appear at the office; he gave me no Christian name, but it was marked H.F.
NOT GUILTY .

264.
JOHN TOWNS
and
WILLIAM HUNT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November , 90 lbs. of lead, value 22s., belonging to
David Evans
, and fixed to his dwelling-house .
SECOND COUNT, stating it to be fixed to a building.

WILLIAM THRESH
. On the 24th of November, about twenty minutes to six o'clock, I was just by Mr. Evans' premises, at the corner of John-street, Crutched-friars
, and met Towns with this piece of lead on his shoulder - he was carrying it openly, and I asked where he was going - he said to take it home to his master; I said it was useless to say that; but to take it back to where he got it from; I had seen him ten minutes or a quarter of an hour before, and asked who he was waiting for; he said for some persons who were at work there; I have since compared the lead with what remains on the premises - it corresponds exactly.

JOHN THOMPSON
. I am a constable. I met Hunt on the 24th of November, a little before six o'clock in the evening, about a quarter of a mile from Mr. Evans' premises, with this piece of lead in this bag; I asked what he had got - he said, "Some wet things;" I felt it was a substance, and found this lead in it; I have compared it with what remains - it corresponds exactly.
DAVID EVANS. This lead was taken from my manufactory, which adjoins my dwelling-house - it belongs to me; I have seen the lead compared with what remains - they correspond exactly.

JOSEPH HUNT
. I am an officer. I took Towns to the Compter; I asked if he had a knife about him; he said No, but I was untying his hands in the Compter, and this knife was in his hands - it appears to have lately cut lead.
TOWN's Defence. I was hired to carry the lead.

TOWNS -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

HUNT -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

265.
JAMES RAVEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of September , 2 sovereigns, 6 half-sovereigns, one 10l., and five 1l. promissory notes , the property of
James Wesson
.

JAMES WESSON. I am a tailor , and live at Saffron-Walden, Essex. On the 26th of September I packed up a parcel, containing a 10l. and 5l. Bank note of Saffron-Walden bank, with six half-sovereigns, and two sovereigns- it was all mine; I packed it in brown paper, and directed it to Mr.
William Aldington Seal
, Minories - it was to go to the Blue Boar public-house, Whitechapel - this is the 10l. note. - I gave the parcel to Spinks to deliver to the Stortford coach; I know nothing of the prisoner.

JOHN SPINKS
. I drive the coach as far as Stortford. I received this brown paper parcel from Wesson on the 26th of September; I locked it in the hind boot - we change coaches at Bishop-Stortford; I took all the parcels out of my coach, and put them into Firman's.

GEORGE FIRMAN
. I drive the Bishop-Stortford coach to town; I did not see this parcel.

JOHN PORTER
. I am porter at the Blue Boar, Whitechapel
. The Bishop-Stortford coach arrived there, about twelve o'clock in the morning, on the 26th of September - the prisoner was horse-keeper there, and helped to unload the coach; I did not help to unload it that day; I know no more of it.

JOHN FORRESTER
. About three weeks after this parcel was taken, I heard the Regulator coach had been robbed of a parcel containing 20l., and, on inquiry, I found the prisoner had left the Blue Boar, and gone to Mrs. Nelson's, at the Bull inn; I went to him, and said, "Young man, I hear you have found a little money;" he said, "Yes, I have;" I said, "How much might it be, pray?" he said a 10l. note; I said, "Where did you find it?" he said, "In Cheapside;" I said, "Was it loose in the street?" he said,"No - it was wrapped in brown paper;" I asked if there was any more; he said, "No - only a 10l. note;" I asked if it was a Bank note - he said, "No - a country note;" I asked where he changed it; he said at Mr. Meason's, the hatter, in Aldgate, and that he gave his address, James Thompson, Leadenhall-street, on the back of it; I went to Mr. Meason, and found this note with that written on it, and here is the hat which he bought; I found thirteen sovereigns in his box.

JOHN STAPLES
. I am in the employ of Mr. Meason, hatter, of Aldgate. I remember the prisoner coming to our house once, previous to buying this hat, which was on the 13th or 14th of October - he paid me a 10l. Saffron-Walden note; I rather doubted its being good, and sent to the Saracen's Head inn, where the Saffron-Walden coach comes, to know if it was good, or if it had been stopped - they did not doubt it - I asked him his address - he said
James Thompson
, Leadenhall-street, and said he worked at Messrs. Cross and Lewis, Fenchurch-street; I paid the note away in the course of the week, and it got down to Saffron-Walden.
JAMES WESSON. This is my note - it came from the Saffron-Walden bank to me; I know it by the number, which I took when I packed it up.
WILLIAM ALDINGTON SEAL. I live at Sparrow-corner Minories. I expected this parcel - it never arrived, and I wrote in consequence of it.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

266.
MARIA FILLINGHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of October , 1 silk handkerchief, value 3s., and 1 pencil-case, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Fitch
, her master; and 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; 1 petticoat, value 3s.; 1 shift, value 3s., and 2 caps, value 2s. , the goods of
Mary Ann Osborne
.

THOMAS FITCH. I live in St. Dunstan's-passage, City
. Mary Ann Osborne is my wife's sister - the prisoner nurse d my wife, who was laying in - a band of ribbon was seen hanging out of her pocket; she was suspected, and taken into custody; and on her person was found a piece of lace, all my wife's keys, and other articles and duplicates.

THOMAS EMBERSON
. I live with Mr. Allers, a pawnbrober. I have several articles pawned by the prisoner in the name of Carter.

RICHARD MORRIS
. I live with Mr. Thomas, a pawnbroker. I have a pencil-case, a shift, a pair of stockings, and cap, pawned, on the 14th of October, by a woman in the name of E. Carter - I cannot say whether it was the prisoner.
MARY ANN OSBORNE. This property is all mine, except the pencil-case and handkerchief; I never gave her leave to take them.

JOHN THOMPSON
. I am an officer. I found the duplicates of this property on the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I intended to redeem them again, and had no idea of defrauding them.
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Transported for Seven Years .

267.
JOHN BEVERLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 1 pair of goloshes, value 11s. , the goods of
Thomas Clarke
.

THOMAS CLARKE. I am a boot-maker , and live in Fleet-street
. About eight o'clock in the evening of the 25th of November, my attention was drawn from the end of the shop, by the head of a person near my window; the prisoner came into the shop, and took this pair of goloshes; I called to my young man - we followed, and took him a few yards off, with them in his hand.

JOSEPH ALVIN
. I am apprentice to Mr. Clarke. He called me; I saw the prisoner going out with the goloshes; we followed, and took him with them. He is a stranger.
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Transported Seven Years .

268.
ROBERT BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of November , 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. , the goods of
Robert Romanis
.

JOHN MOODY
. I am shopman to Robert Romanis, a hosier , of Cheapside
. On the 18th of November, about eight o'clock at night, I was coming into the shop, and saw the prisoner snatch these stockings from inside the door, and run down Friday-street; I followed, but could not overtake him - he turned down Distaff-lane - I lost sight of him for a few seconds - he then turned back, and asked what I wanted with him - he had nothing then - I called the watchman, who took him; I went down Distaff-lane, and found these stockings in a grating.

WILLIAM DANCE
. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner run down Friday-street and turn into Distaff-lane. Moody called to me to take him, and we met him coming back towards Friday-street - I took him to the watch-house; and on going along, he said, "This will only be a three weeks' spell for me again."

EDWARD SORRELL
. I am watch-house keeper. The prisoner was brought there with the stockings.
MR. ROBERT ROMANIS. These are my stockings; they were inside the shop.
Prisoner's Defence. I was with another boy; he snatched the stockings; I ran after him; - they hung quite outside the door.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Months .

269.
HENRY GUPPY
and
JAMES CROKER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Roger Hunt
, from his person .

ROGER HUNT. I am a clerk in the office of the Bank Solicitor . I was on Ludgate-hill
on the 9th of November; there was no procession passing then; my handkerchief was in my left-hand coat-pocket; I heard a sudden scuffle behind me; I turned round, and saw the officer holding Croker by the collar: he had my handkerchief in his hand; I then missed it from my pocket: - I saw Guppy at a short distance - he stood for a moment, and then ran down the hill.

JOSEPH PINE
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I was coming up Ludgate-hill - I saw the two prisoners and another following two gentlemen very closely; I then saw Guppy take Mr. Hunt's handkerchief and give it to Croker. I ran and took Guppy.

ROBERT TYRRELL
. I was with Pine. I saw Guppy take the handkerchief, and give it to Croker, whom I seized as he was putting it under his coat - he dropped it - and I took it up.

GUPPY -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

CROKER -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

270.
THOMAS JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of December , one 10l. Bank note , the property of
George Jaques
.

GEORGE JAQUES. I am an attorney's-clerk - I live in Friar-street, Blackfriar's-road. I was going up Ludgate-hill on the 8th of December, a little before ten o'clock; the prisoner overtook me, and when I had reached the corner of Creed-lane, some person walking before us dropped a pin-case - and then the prisoner (or some person very much like him) stooped and said he had found something, and he would have a bit of fun with the person who dropped it - he thought he was a tailor, and he would bother him a bit by taking the needles out and putting in a pin; I advised him to do nothing of the sort, but to return it to the person with the needles in it, but he persisted in putting his plan into execution; I did not see what he did with it, but he called to the person before, and asked if he had lost any thing; he said, Yes - he had lost a needle-case; he said, "What is there in it?" the man said, "There is a needle;" the prisoner said, "Are you sure there was a needle in it?" the man said, Yes; the prisoner said, "I will bet you three cups of coffee there is not;" he said he would bet him a 5l. note of it; the prisoner said, "No, I will not bet 5l., I will bet you three cups of coffee;" the other said, "No, I will not bet so small a sum as that - I will bet 5l.; and he said hebelieved the prisoner had no money in his pocket to bet with; I advised the man not to bet his 5l. with the prisoner, as I thought the prisoner had changed it - the man got very violent, because I interfered - and said he believed I had no money in my pocket; I was a little off my guard, and was induced to bet the 5l. wager; we stopped at the end of Creed-lane
, and then the wager was made; I said I would bet 5l. with the man who dropped it, that there was not a needle in the case; I covered it with a 10l. note, and the money was put into the hand of the prisoner - I did it under an impression that the prisoner had taken it out, and with a view of returning him the 5l. note- another person then came up, and the money was put into his hands - the needle-case was produced, and a needle and a pin were found in it; the person who dropped it opened it, and there was a needle and pin in it - they ran away.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. You were pretty sure you should win? A. Yes - I did not intend to pocket his 5l.; I should not have kept it if I had won. I swear that - I am clerk to Mr. Downes - it was his note; I cannot swear the prisoner is the man.
NOT GUILTY .

271.
JOHN STRAHAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 8d., and 3lbs. weight of velvet strippings, value 1s., the goods of
Daniel Smith
, from the person of
Daniel Shopperson
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First London Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

272.
EDWARD ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December , 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
Charles Cunningham
, from his person .

CHARLES CUNNINGHAM. I am a mercer , and live in Bernard-street, Russell-square. On the 7th of December, I was in Lothbury
, about five o'clock in the evening, and had a handkerchief in my coat pocket; I felt some one turn up my pocket; I turned round and saw the prisoner very near me: he passed me as I put my hand at my pocket: I examined my hat to see if it was there: - I then went and said to the prisoner, "Have you by chance found my handkerchief?" I saw it in his hand - he said Yes. I said I know where you found it, and detained him.

SAMUEL TURNER
. I am a constable. I took him in charge, with the handkerchief - he said he had picked it up, but it was a rainy dirty evening, and the handkerchief was quite clean.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw it laying in a door-way - a gentleman saw me pick it up, but I have not had time to send for him.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

273.
JOHN MANLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of November , 1 wooden-box, value 1s. 6d.; 1 book, value 1s.; 34 pots of tomato-paste, value 3l., and 4 ozs. of gum-paste ornaments, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Russell
, and others.

JOHN CHASE
. I am book-keeper to T. Russell and others, who are carriers , and live in Friday-street, Cheapside. On the 18th of November the prisoner came into the office, and asked if the Colchester waggon went from there - I said, No; and as he went out I saw him take a box - I went into the yard, and asked the porters if he had brought one in - they said, No; I called to him; he took no notice - I sent the porters after him; they brought him back, and he said he had taken the wrong box, and it was heavier than the one he brought - I told him to put it down where he took it from, and take the one he had brought; he could not find that; he was a stranger; the one he took had come from Plymouth, and contained this property.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a porter at this inn. I saw the prisoner come up the yard; he had no box; he came out of the warehouse with one; Chase sent me after him, and he said he had made a mistake; he returned with me, and put it down.

STEPHEN SIMPSON
. I am a porter at this inn. I met the prisoner going into the warehouse; he had no box then.

JOHN WILLIS
. I am an officer, and took him in charge.

ROBERT ORTON
. I packed up this box at Plymouth; it contains the articles stated in the indictment.
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

274.
THOMAS COURTNEY LLOYD
was indicted for
perjury .
MR. LAW (on behalf of the Prosecution) declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

275.
ELLEN McDONALD
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .
MR. LAW conducted the prosecution.

MARK LEVI
. I live in Swan-court, Petticoat-lane, and sell fruit
. On the 9th of November , about half-past three o'clock, the prisoner asked the price of a few nuts, which I had in my basket; I said 1d. - she asked if I could change a half-crown, which she gave me; I gave her four sixpences and 5d.; a cart was passing, and I lost sight of her in a moment - I looked at the half-crown, and found it was bad - I have kept it separate from others - I saw her in the custody of Levison in half an hour; she handed my change to another woman; and when I sounded the half-crown, I missed them both; I had seen her several times.

JACOB ARDETI
(through an interpreter). I live in Petticoat-lane
. About four weeks ago, as I stood in Harrow-alley, Petticoat-lane, the prisoner asked to buy a pair of slippers for 3d., and gave me a bad shilling, which I returned to her - I saw Levison there - he took the shilling from her.

ABRAHAM LEVISON
. I saw the prisoner with Ardeti; I took the shilling from her, and delivered it with her to Forrester; I saw her throw something among the people; I could not find it.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am a constable, and received her in charge with the shilling; she had not a half-penny about her.

JOHN FIELD
. I am Inspector of money; this half-crown and shilling are both counterfeits.
Prisoner's Defence. I took the shilling in the lane.
GUILTY. Of uttering the half-crown only .

Confined Six Months , and to
find Sureties .

276.
REBECCA CARLTON
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

JOHN BASTABLE
. I am a butcher , and live in Long-lane
. On the 11th of November , the prisoner came into my shop, about four o'clock, and bought a sheep's heart, which came to 3d., and paid me a bad shilling - I gave her a 6d. and 3d.; on her going out, I sounded the shilling - my son-in-law said it was bad, and fetched her back; my daughter searched her - I gave the shilling to Todd.

THOMAS TODD
. I am Bastable's son-in-law - I fetched the prisoner back; my wife searched her; she resisted a great deal - my wife found she had a pocket behind, between her shoulders; she called for help, and the officer went in - I took the shilling, and gave it to Pye.

EDWARD JONES
. I am a milkman - the prisoner was brought back to the shop by Todd; he showed me the shilling; she was taken into the back-parlour.

THOMAS PYE
. I am a constable. I saw her searched, and the pocket found; Jones gave me the shilling - fifteen counterfeit shillings were in the coat-pocket; and in her basket were several odd articles of provisions, all in small quantities.

JOHN FIELD
. This shilling and these fifteen are all counterfeit, and from the same die.
Prisoner. I found the packet in Long-lane - I was so rejoiced, I took out 1s., and went to buy a heart.
GUILTY . Aged 12.

Confined One Year , and
find Sureties for Two Years .

277.
MARY GARRON
was indicted for
fraud .

ELIZABETH SAUNDERS
. I am barmaid to
W. Shaw Hill
, who keeps a wine-vaults in Fore-street
. On the 31st of October , about three o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came there, and said she wanted a bottle of gin for Mr. Johnson - she was formerly in the habit of coming for Mr. Johnson, of Wood-street, and I let her have it; she never had any before, without paying for it.

SAMUEL JOHNSON
. The prisoner was my housemaid ; I have sent her to Hill's for wine, but not spirits - she left me on the 28th of October; I did not send her on the 31st- she lived about fifteen months with me. I believe her husband has misled her.

JOSEPH HORTON
. I am an officer, and took her in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Strongly Recommended to Mercy.
Confined One Month .

The KING against DUNN
and SMITH
.

On the second day of the Sessions, Mr. JUSTICE PARK delivered the decision of the Twelve Judges upon the above Case, which confirmed the conviction. Dunn has accordingly received sentence of
Death - and Smith of
Transportation for Fourteen Years . The particulars of the above decision shall appear in the next Report.
